author: By Rory Smith
title: Norway Has a Must-See Team. Barely Anyone Can Watch It.
description: Bodo/Glimt is on the cusp of its first championship, a soccer success story built on style and innovation. But its golden year has played out in front of nearly empty stands.
content: The best perch is on the rooftop overlooking the stadium. Reaching it is not for the fainthearted: The only access is via an external staircase, and most of the field can be seen only if you sit right on the lip of the building. But still, during most games, a handful of hardy fans have made the journey up there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen I. Vladeck
title: Elections Don’t Have to Be So Chaotic and Excruciating
description: The random way in which returns were released caused anxiety and sowed conspiracy theories.
content: Joe Biden ended up winning the presidency with at least 279 electoral votes, a margin that seems comfortable now that the election is over. But for the public watching the ups and downs of the piecemeal vote count and the drip drip drip of results, the process was torturous — and offered President Trump and his allies the opportunity to conjure conspiracy theories to explain away his defeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: As a Bitter Election Ends, 26 Americans Look to the Future
description: We asked voters about their hopes for the next four years — regardless of the occupant in the White House.
content: Election night played out as one more anxious chapter in a year characterized by bitter partisan rancor and successive national crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: A Nation Votes for Joe Biden, and a Red State Shrugs
description: Nebraska delivered one electoral vote for Mr. Biden, but the rest of the rural state is deeply red, and mostly accepting of the election results.
content: YUTAN, Neb. — In the moments after the presidential vote tally made it clear that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had won the election on Saturday, a teenager wheeled a broken lawn mower across an empty downtown street here. Wispy white clouds blew across the sky. Inside the Rusty Rooster Saloon, a man with gray hair took a swig from a Bud Light can, and the only result that interested anyone was the outcome of the college football game on the television.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Prakash Elumalai
title: Joy in India as Biden and Harris Win, but Questions, Too
description: Kamala Harris’s ancestral village in southern India rejoiced on Sunday. But across the country, many wonder what changes the new administration will bring.
content: NEW DELHI — From the moment the sun came up in Thulasendrapuram, a little village in southern India, people started stringing firecrackers across the road. They poured into the temple. They took colored powder and wrote exuberant messages in big, happy letters in front of their homes, like this one:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make Genevieve Ko’s apple pie, full of as many different apple varieties as you can manage.
content: Good morning. Genevieve Ko recently joined our team, coming to us from The Los Angeles Times, where she was cooking editor. She’s in our Times this week with a smart, comforting, easy take on apple pie (above) that I think would make for a fine Sunday project for you at a time when pie seems very much in order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Conor Lamb, House Moderate, on Biden’s Win, ‘the Squad’ and the Future of the Democratic Party
description: Conor Lamb, who survived a Republican challenge in Pennsylvania, says Democrats were given a message on Election Day: Backlash to progressive policies risks killing their House majority.
content: The carefully calibrated unity of the Democratic Party lasted about six months. After a summer when moderates and progressives joined together to elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. president, his victory has now given permission for the party to expend time and energy on the difficult task of sorting out its ideological core.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: As Biden Plans Transition, Republicans Decline to Recognize His Election
description: Former President George W. Bush and a handful of other Republicans congratulated the president-elect, but most party leaders stayed quiet or urged President Trump to fight.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. prepared on Sunday to start building his administration, even as Republican leaders and scores of party lawmakers refrained from acknowledging his victory out of apparent deference to President Trump, who continued to refuse to concede.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Seymour Topping, Former Times Journalist and Eyewitness to History, Dies at 98
description: He was one of the most accomplished foreign correspondents of his generation and a newsroom leader under the renowned executive editor A.M. Rosenthal.
content: Seymour Topping, who chronicled the rise of China and the Cold War in Europe and Asia as a correspondent, shaped the crowning years of print journalism as an editor of The New York Times, and led the charge into the internet age in the classrooms of Columbia University, died on Sunday in White Plains, N.Y. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez on Biden’s Win, House Losses, and What’s Next for the Left
description: The congresswoman said Joe Biden’s relationship with progressives would hinge on his actions. And she dismissed criticism from House moderates, calling some candidates who lost their races “sitting ducks.”
content: For months, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has been a good soldier for the Democratic Party and Joseph R. Biden Jr. as he sought to defeat President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Azerbaijan Claims Capture of Key Town in Nagorno-Karabakh
description: The country asserted on Sunday that its military had gained control of a strategically important site that overlooks the regional capital, Stepanakert. Armenian officials said fighting continued.
content: TVER, Russia — The president of Azerbaijan claimed on Sunday that his forces had captured a strategically important hilltop town in Nagorno-Karabakh, which, if confirmed, would greatly complicate Armenia’s defense of the separatist region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: 9 Things the Biden Administration Could Do Quickly on the Environment
description: The first 100 days of the Biden administration are likely to see a flurry of executive actions on climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigned on the most ambitious climate platform of any presidential candidate in history, promising to spend $2 trillion over four years to draw down planet-warming fossil fuel emissions and convert much of the nation to clean energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: ‘Liftoff!’
description: Kate Hawkins opens our solving week with her New York Times Crossword.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — One of the nice things about writing this column is that there is a constant influx of people to meet. Reasonably, the newer solvers among them have not had the experience with crosswords to recognize that there are some theme types that are popular enough to be repeated, with the constructors putting a small spin on their ideas in order to make them their own. I think that familiarizing yourself with the theme types helps improve solving quite a lot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: It’s President-elect Joe Biden.
content: Foreign leaders showered the U.S. president-elect with congratulations. For many, the importance of this election was as much about removing President Trump as ushering in Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: A Famed Fig Tree’s Days Are Numbered as a New Highway Plows Through
description: A tree that has graced a neighborhood in Nairobi, Kenya, for nearly a century is slated to be taken down to make way for a highway through the city intended to reduce traffic jams.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — The fig tree, four stories high and almost a century old, its arched branches forming a giant canopy, has served as a landmark for generations of Kenyans in the bustling commercial neighborhood of Westlands in the capital, Nairobi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Read Kamala Harris’s Vice President-Elect Acceptance Speech
description: In her remarks Saturday night, Vice President-elect Kamala Harris acknowledged “all the women who have worked to secure and protect the right to vote” and said: “And I stand on their shoulders.”
content: Kamala Harris, the first woman, the first Black woman, and the first woman of Indian heritage to be elected vice president, said Saturday that “a new day for America” had arrived and thanked Americans for making their voices heard in a brief speech on Saturday night, hours after she and Joseph R. Biden Jr. had been declared the winners of the 2020 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Europe Lauds Biden but Wonders: What Will He Want? How Long Will He Stay?
description: Allies welcomed an American president who sees them as allies, not rivals. But with the U.S. so polarized, and with the possibility of a Republican-controlled Senate, they are also wary.
content: BRUSSELS — In the “America First” landscape that President Trump created, Joseph R. Biden Jr. was an outdated romantic trans-Atlanticist. So there is relief in Europe about having a well-disposed friend in the White House who is more likely to support than to berate, harangue and insult.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Read Joe Biden’s President-Elect Acceptance Speech: Full Transcript
description: In his victory speech, delivered after days of vote counting and uncertainty, Mr. Biden renewed his promise to be a president for all Americans in a polarized time.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr., a 77-year-old former vice president and longtime senator who has sought the White House on and off for more than three decades, on Saturday renewed his commitment to unifying and serving all Americans at a time the nation is deeply divided along sharply drawn partisan lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: George W. Bush congratulates Biden on his victory.
description: The former president became the highest profile Republican to publicly call the election in defiance of President Trump’s refusal to accept the results.
content: Former President George W. Bush congratulated President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Sunday, becoming the highest-profile Republican to publicly declare the election over in defiance of President Trump’s refusal to accept the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: In Pennsylvania, Trump Voter Fury Foretells a Nation Still Divided
description: President Trump has presented no hard evidence of voter fraud, but his charges have riled supporters in Pennsylvania who now insist the election has been stolen.
content: PITTSBURGH — Like many Trump supporters, Dennis Tippie watched the steady tallying of votes that wiped away the president’s early lead in Pennsylvania, not with a faith that democracy was playing out but with dark and rising anger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: Biden calls for unity in his first address to the nation as president-elect.
description: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the nation for the first time as president-elect on Saturday night, delivering a message of unity and trying to soothe the extraordinary divisions that defined the last four years in American politics.
content: WILMINGTON, Del. — Joseph R. Biden Jr. addressed the nation for the first time as president-elect on Saturday night, delivering a message of unity and trying to soothe the extraordinary divisions that defined the last four years in American politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck
title: Biden’s concern for ‘the soul of this country’ drove his successful campaign.
description: On a January evening in 2019, Joseph R. Biden Jr. placed a call to the mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, a personal friend and political ally who had just announced he would not pursue the Democratic nomination for president.
content: On a January evening in 2019, Joseph R. Biden Jr. placed a call to the mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, a personal friend and political ally who had just announced he would not pursue the Democratic nomination for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Courtney Rubin
title: Call It Friendsgiving, Call It Podsgiving, Just Don’t Forget the Green Beans
description: Thanksgiving is even more of a logistical puzzle this year, and some people are solving it differently.
content: When Linda Coats realized she would not be able to host her children and grandchildren for Thanksgiving this year because of the pandemic, she and her husband considered volunteering at a soup kitchen and skipping the turkey dinner entirely. Instead, they decided to spend the holiday with their second family: Their neighbors in  Lexington Park, Md.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkey’s Finance Minister Resigns Amid Pressures of Sliding Economy
description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s son-in-law, who is known for his ties to the Trump White House, said he was quitting as Turkey’s lira tumbles and its economy worsens.
content: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s finance minister, Berat Albayrak, the son-in-law of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, announced his resignation Sunday evening amid escalating fallout over the country’s collapsing economy and plunging currency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Alex Trebek, Longtime Host of ‘Jeopardy!,’ Dies at 80
description: A good host, he once said, could set his ego aside and let contestants be all they could be. But he let them know when he thought they missed easy answers.
content: At a restaurant several years ago, a stranger went up to Alex Trebek, the longtime host of “Jeopardy!” and as strangers often did, tried to stump him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns, Jonathan Martin and Katie Glueck
title: How Joe Biden Won the Presidency
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. campaigned as a sober and conventional presence, concerned about the “soul of the country.” He correctly judged the character of the country, and benefited from President Trump’s missteps.
content: On a January evening in 2019, Joseph R. Biden Jr. placed a call to the mayor of Los Angeles, Eric Garcetti, a personal friend and political ally who had just announced he would not pursue the Democratic nomination for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Putin Is Mum on Biden’s Victory, Foreshadowing Tense Years Ahead
description: Early signs indicate that Russia’s leader is preparing for a deeply adversarial relationship with the next U.S. president.
content: MOSCOW — The morning after Joseph R. Biden Jr. became president-elect of the United States, the Kremlin published a congratulatory message from President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Howie Meeker, Hockey Star and Colorful Broadcaster, Dies at 97
description: Meeker was known for his candid remarks about players and the games. He came to television after a career as an All-Star for the Toronto Maple Leafs.
content: Howie Meeker, who played on four Stanley Cup championship teams with the Toronto Maple Leafs and went on to become a Hockey Hall of Fame broadcaster for his innovative and colorful commentary, mostly with the hugely popular “Hockey Night in Canada” telecasts of the 1970s and 80s, died on Sunday at a hospital in Nanaimo, British Columbia, on Vancouver Island. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Godwyn Morris and Paula Frisch
title: Put Physics to the Test With a D.I.Y. Roller Coaster
description: Build supports and track from newspaper and then put them together in your own combinations.
content: While riding a roller coaster may not be an option these days, building your own from newspaper can be. Harness the first of Newton’s laws of motion — that objects keep moving in the same direction unless something gets in the way — to create an action-packed roller coaster game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James S. Russell
title: With Help From Herb Alpert, Letting the Light In at the Harlem School of the Arts
description: Dorothy Maynor never sang at the Met, but the school she founded is glowing anew, thanks to the revitalization of its beloved “gathering place.”
content: A typical Saturday at the Harlem School of the Arts would find families chatting with each other as one child runs out of a dance class in tights, or another lugs a viola. A quick bite or check-in with parents, and they would dash to a drawing or singing class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Host a Multigenerational Game Night This Thanksgiving
description: With the family together for the holiday, you might be looking for tabletop games that will delight kids and grown-ups alike. Here are a few you can all play together.
content: Monopoly takes forever. Candy Land is dull, Chutes and Ladders preachy, the Game of Life troubling in its implications. So even as parents scramble for offscreen entertainment over the holidays, the prospect of a family game night may drive them to despair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor, Mark Landler, Vivian Wang, Austin Ramzy and Damien Cave
title: In a tweet, Netanyahu congratulates Biden, praising their ‘warm personal relationship.’
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, a staunch ally of President Trump’s who had a chilly relationship with former President Barack Obama, congratulated Joseph R. Biden Jr. early Sunday, despite Mr. Trump’s insistence that the U.S. election was not over.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, a staunch ally of President Trump’s who had a chilly relationship with former President Barack Obama, congratulated Joseph R. Biden Jr. early Sunday, despite Mr. Trump’s insistence that the U.S. election was not over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Kansas Democrat Who Admitted to Revenge Porn Wins State House Seat
description: Now, state party leaders are looking to replace the representative-elect, Aaron Coleman.
content: Aaron Coleman’s election to the Kansas House of Representatives would have been remarkable for a young candidate trying to unseat an incumbent. But it has instead left state Democratic leaders saying that they will take “every necessary step” to ensure that Mr. Coleman is not seated in the State Legislature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Richard Fausset
title: How Georgia Turned From Reliably Republican to Political Ground Zero
description: Joe Biden’s narrow lead in Georgia and the runoffs that will determine control of the Senate have raised questions as to whether 2020 is a Trumpian aberration or a long-anticipated political shift.
content: MARIETTA, Ga. — It took a lifetime for Angie Jones to become a Democrat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Simon Marks
title: Ethiopia’s Leader Reshuffles Top Security Officials Amid Tigray Conflict
description: The new appointments came as the military operation in the northern Tigray region entered its fifth day, with the United Nations saying the stoppage of air and road access was affecting humanitarian operations.
content: CAIRO — Ethiopia’s prime minister reshuffled his country’s security services on Sunday, days after he ordered a military offensive in the northern Tigray region, edging the country toward a potential all-out civil war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Aubry Kaplan
title: Black Empowerment Outside the Headlines
description: A quiet battle over retail space is a modern fight for the soul of Black Los Angeles.
content: LOS ANGELES — Even as the post-George Floyd national focus on the grand battle against systemic racism and all things Black plateaus, ground battles for equity that have been fought for decades continue. One such fight here in Los Angeles is reaching a critical point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Five Takeaways From President-Elect Biden’s Victory Speech
description: As he addressed the nation from Delaware, Joseph R. Biden Jr. set a tone that was very different from President Trump’s.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. waited a long time to give the speech he delivered in Delaware on Saturday night. Not just the five days since Election Day, but arguably the 48 years since he was first elected to the Senate, during which he ran for president three times. And at age 77, as Mr. Biden came trotting up the runway to an explosion of car horns and cheers, beaming and looking almost surprised by the ovation, it was clear that his moment had arrived.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: What We Learned From Week 9 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Buffalo’s offense exploded against Seattle, the Ravens and the Chiefs held on for wins, the Steelers improved to 8-0 and the Saints humiliated the Buccaneers.
content: Pittsburgh came back from an early deficit against Dallas to improve to 8-0, Kansas City had to sweat a little against Carolina, Buffalo throttled Seattle and Baltimore’s defense carried the team against Indianapolis. And the night finished with New Orleans enjoying a fairly ridiculous blowout against Tampa Bay. Sunday didn’t have any huge upsets, but there was plenty of excitement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Lisa Friedman
title: Biden Could Roll Back Trump Agenda With Blitz of Executive Actions
description: For Joseph R. Biden Jr., who won the election in a deeply divided nation, the early signals he sends as the country’s new leader will be critical.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is poised to unleash a series of executive actions on his first day in the Oval Office, prompting what is likely to be a yearslong effort to unwind President Trump’s domestic agenda and immediately signal a wholesale shift in the United States’ place in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: Covid Infections in Animals Prompt Scientific Concern
description: Mink in Denmark are not the only animals that could become reservoirs for the coronavirus to spread new mutations to people.
content: The decision this week by the Danish government to kill millions of mink because of coronavirus concerns, effectively wiping out a major national industry, has put the spotlight on simmering worries among scientists and conservationists about the vulnerability of animals to the pandemic virus, and what infections among animals could mean for humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Why the Biden Economy Could Be the Same Long Slog as the Obama Economy
description: With continuing Republican control of the Senate likely, the sort of large-scale stimulus some economists have urged may be off the table.
content: The way things are shaping up, the Biden economy appears likely to show uncanny similarities to the 2011-to-2016 Obama economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Burns
title: Check in on Health Insurance Open Enrollment
description: If you’re shopping for health insurance this fall for coverage starting Jan. 1, start early and set aside a full day to learn about your options.
content: Amid uncertainty during a pandemic and a U.S. Supreme Court challenge, open enrollment in health insurance marketplaces began on Nov. 1. In all 50 states, individuals and families who lack insurance or want better coverage can enroll in plans that comply with the Affordable Care Act through Dec. 15, although enrollment ends later in 10 states and the District of Columbia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Norm Crosby, Comedian Who Had a (Wrong) Way With Words, Dies at 93
description: “I was doing everybody’s material,” he said, before discovering his own shtick and becoming the master of the malaprop.
content: Norm Crosby, the comedian known as the master of malaprop because he spoke from his diagram and related many funny antidotes, often to a standing ovulation, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Biden to Restore a White House Tradition of Presidential Pets
description: President Trump was the first president not to have a White House pet in more than 100 years. Mr. Biden will bring two German shepherds, one of which was adopted from a shelter.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. is expected to restore a time-honored tradition of having a presidential pet at the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kirk Semple
title: China Extends Reach in the Caribbean, Unsettling the U.S.
description: The region has strategic importance as a hub for logistics, banking and commerce. It is also very close to the United States.
content: MEXICO CITY — China has offered Jamaica loans and expertise to build miles of new highways. Throughout the Caribbean, it has donated security equipment to military and police forces, and built a network of Chinese cultural centers. And it has dispatched large shipments of test kits, masks and ventilators to help governments respond to the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caren Osten Gerszberg
title: Prepare for Your College Student’s Return for the Holidays
description: Plan out the trip home and set ground rules for safe socializing. And remember that they’ve had a tough year, too, so give them the space to talk about it.
content: For college students, this has been a semester like no other. The majority attended classes online and, because of coronavirus surges on campus, they have had to endure a host of restrictions — from rules against socializing to fewer dining options to limited or no access to libraries and gyms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Norwegian soccer club wins as never before, while the pandemic distances its fans.
description: This has been a golden year for the soccer club in Bodo, Norway, a city of 50,000 that sits at the southern end of the Arctic Circle. The club, Bodo/Glimt, stands on the cusp of claiming its first Norwegian championship.
content: This has been a golden year for the soccer club in Bodo, Norway, a city of 50,000 that sits at the southern end of the Arctic Circle. The club, Bodo/Glimt, stands on the cusp of claiming its first Norwegian championship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Kamala Harris in a White Suit, Dressing for History
description: This wasn’t about fashion, it was about politics, past and future.
content: On Saturday night, when Kamala Harris stepped onto the stage and into history at the Chase Center in Wilmington, Del., as Vice President-elect of the United States, she did so in full recognition of the weight of the moment, and in full acknowledgment of all who came before. Of the fact she is so many firsts: first woman to be vice president, first woman of color to be vice president, first woman of South Asian descent, first daughter of immigrants. She is the representation of so many promises finally fulfilled, so many hopes and dreams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: Review: ‘Industry’ Is a Familiar Story, but With More Zeros
description: The new HBO series, executive produced by Lena Dunham, is set in the world of high finance but feels like many other shows about young adults trying to make it.
content: Look to your left. Look to your right. One of us is watching a show that’s so uninterested in originality that some character trots out that speech you’ve heard so many times before: One of you won’t finish this prestigious, grueling program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas, Audra D. S. Burch, Evan Nicole Brown and Richard Fausset
title: ‘A Long Time Coming’: Black Women Celebrate Harris’s Ascension
description: As Kamala Harris heads toward the highest levels of power, many rejoiced and saw her achievement as a particularly poignant reminder to Black girls that anything is possible.
content: ATLANTA — When Yolanda Latimore, the owner of a Macon, Ga., advertising agency, makes a list of those who showed her how to survive and thrive as a Black woman, she begins with her 91-year-old grandmother, Clarise Bonner, a former sharecropper who lacked a formal education yet ran a small business while also raising a family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Ravens Leave Loss in Rearview Mirror With Decisive Win Over Colts
description: Baltimore forced three timely turnovers and bounced back after a dismal first half to hold off one of the A.F.C.’s toughest challengers.
content: John Harbaugh’s paternal grandfather, Bill, was an awful driver, and as a tumultuous week dawned for the Baltimore Ravens, the coach felt compelled to share as much with his players.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Despite Warnings, the Election Actually Ran Smoothly
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, November 8, 2020.
content: “We are a raucous, dysfunctional family who will stand together in the best of times and in the worst of times. If you can’t believe that then you have no business running American elections.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Earthquake Rattles Parts of Massachusetts and Rhode Island
description: The quake, which had a preliminary magnitude of 3.6, was also felt in the Long Island Sound, the United States Geological Survey said.
content: A minor earthquake rumbled through parts of Connecticut, Massachusetts and Rhode Island on Sunday morning, according to the United States Geological Survey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘Saturday Night Live’ Sends Off Trump With a Ballad
description: Alec Baldwin appeared as the president to mourn the election results, and the host Dave Chappelle urged Americans to “find a way to forgive each other.”
content: Just over four years ago, “Saturday Night Live” invited Dave Chappelle to host its Nov. 12, 2016 broadcast — the show’s first after that year’s presidential election. The tacit assumption, at the time, was that he would be the master of ceremonies for an episode that would serve as both a satirical farewell to the long-shot candidacy of the Republican nominee, Donald J. Trump, and a victory lap for his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer and Katie Glueck
title: Dancing in the Streets, and a Parking Lot, for Joe Biden
description: Defeating President Trump can do strange things for a man’s reputation.
content: People have not historically hustled to spontaneous outdoor dance parties for Joe Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Giants Hold Off Washington’s Late Charge to Win Second Game
description: The Giants’ 17-point halftime lead dwindled, but two interceptions thrown by Washington in the final minutes ended its comeback bid.
content: LANDOVER, Md. — Daniel Jones completed his longest pass of the season, didn’t turn over the ball for the first time and the Giants defeated the Washington Football Team, 23-20, on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Woman Who Says She Was Fired for Being a Lesbian Is Elected Sheriff
description: Charmaine McGuffey, an ex-major in the Hamilton County Sheriff’s Office in Ohio, defeated her former boss in a primary and won the general election against a candidate the sheriff had backed.
content: After rising through the ranks for 33 years, winning awards and becoming the first female major in the Hamilton County Sheriff’s Office in Ohio, Charmaine McGuffey was ousted in 2017, she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Steve Eder and Eric Lipton
title: What’s Next for Trump? The Family Business Awaits His Return
description: President Trump has long complained that public office cost him billions. Now he faces the challenge of jump-starting the company that bears his name, while television also beckons.
content: President Trump’s tax records show signs of financial distress, he claims to have lost out on billions of dollars in income while in office and his eldest sons say the family business has forfeited dozens of potential deals across the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 8, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Nov. 8, 2020.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Page 12 about the composer Osvaldo Golijov misidentifies the person who programmed the 2006 Ojai Music Festival. It was Robert Spano, not Thomas W. Morris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Build Mental Endurance Like a Pro
description: Athletes who have endured the most grueling tests have a lot to tell us about how to thrive in the pandemic.
content: There’s a special kind of exhaustion that the world’s best endurance athletes embrace. Some call it masochistic, others may call it brave. When fatigue sends legs and lungs to their limits, they are able to push through to a gear beyond their pain threshold. These athletes approach fatigue not with fear but as a challenge, an opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: The Digital Nomads Did Not Prepare for This
description: They moved to exotic locales to work through the pandemic in style. But now tax trouble, breakups and Covid guilt are setting in.
content: For a certain kind of worker, the pandemic presented a rupture in the space-time-career continuum. Many Americans were stuck, tied down by children or lost income or obligations to take care of the sick. But for those who were unencumbered, with steady jobs that were doable from anywhere, it was a moment to grab destiny and bend employment to their favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 9, 2020
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘Lost in the Deep’
description: The epic hunt for a lost World War II aircraft carrier.
content: On the afternoon of Sept. 15, 1942, the U.S.S. Wasp, an aircraft carrier housing 71 planes, 2,247 sailors and a journalist, was hit by torpedoes fired by a Japanese submarine, sending it more than two and a half miles to the bottom of the Pacific. It has remained there ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Jeanna Smialek, Ana Swanson and Jim Tankersley
title: In a Divided Washington, Biden Could Still Exert Economic Power
description: If Republicans control the Senate, a Biden administration could take a cue from President Trump and find ways to act unilaterally on some economic issues.
content: WASHINGTON — President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. will take office in January with a weak economy weighed down by the resurgence of the coronavirus, millions of Americans still unemployed and businesses struggling and shuttering as winter bears down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Authentic Gets ‘Emotional’ Breeders’ Cup Win for John Velazquez
description: Velazquez, a Hall of Famer, said getting to ride Authentic during this difficult year was “a gift from God.”
content: John Velazquez climbed aboard Authentic on Saturday afternoon with confidence as well as determination to make a vision come true. His mother-in-law told him she had a good feeling about the $6 million Breeders’ Cup Classic. He and his colt, she told him, were going to win a race that had eluded him 19 times before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: The Election Made Markets Happy
description: The election was good to business and tech. Uber and Lyft won a labor law victory and drug companies saw gains in many states.
content: The days ahead may bring more turmoil, but the worst uncertainty is behind us. (And at least you’re not a Danish mink.) Here’s how Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory affects business and tech, and what to know for the coming week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
title: Christian Conservatives Respond to Trump’s Loss and Look Ahead
description: Many reflected on how much they had gained in the last four years under the Trump administration.
content: When President Trump won the White House four years ago in a surprise victory, conservative Christians could not believe their good fortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Sydney Ember and Jacey Fortin
title: Kamala Harris, elected V.P., has risen higher in national politics than any woman before her.
description: Kamala Harris, a senator from California and former presidential candidate, made history when she was elected vice president of the United States.
content: Kamala Harris, a senator from California and former presidential candidate, made history when she was elected vice president of the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Jeopardy!’ Fans Can’t Imagine the Show Without Alex Trebek
description: Ex-contestants, celebrities and game show enthusiasts mourned the loss of Mr. Trebek, who died on Sunday after battling pancreatic cancer.
content: For television viewers under a certain age, there was never a “Jeopardy!” without Alex Trebek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Goldfarb
title: Solo on the Holiday? Reach Out
description: Single people make up one third of all American households and  finding ways to celebrate this Thanksgiving means taking action ahead of time.
content: Thanksgiving and the holidays that follow are going to look different for everyone this year, but for those who live alone, these changes might hit particularly hard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: China’s state-run news media reacts to Biden’s victory with cautious optimism.
description: HONG KONG — China’s state news media reacted with cautious optimism to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the United States’ presidential election, expressing hope that he would stabilize the fast-deteriorating relations between the two countries.
content: HONG KONG — China’s state news media reacted with cautious optimism to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the United States’ presidential election, expressing hope that he would stabilize the fast-deteriorating relations between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Tropical Storm Eta Makes Landfall in the Florida Keys After Strengthening
description: The 28th named storm of the Atlantic season brought strong winds and heavy rains late Sunday, the National Hurricane Center said.
content: Tropical Storm Eta, the 28th named storm of this year’s busy hurricane season, made landfall on the central part of the Florida Keys late Sunday night, bringing strong winds and heavy rains to the region, the National Hurricane Center said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: O Captain, My ‘Jeopardy!’ Captain
description: When Alex Trebek stepped up to the answer board, night after night, class was in session.
content: For more than 35 years, he was introduced with, “And now, here is the host of ‘Jeopardy!’ … Alex Trebek!” But “host” never seemed quite the right term for what Trebek did.
source.name: The New York Times

title: We followed one Trump supporter from elation to resignation.
description: WILMINGTON, Mass. — Nick Rocco went into Election Day amped up. A 26-year-old hair stylist, he spent the past few months campaigning for President Trump, taking special satisfaction in offending Biden supporters.
content: WILMINGTON, Mass. — Nick Rocco went into Election Day amped up. A 26-year-old hair stylist, he spent the past few months campaigning for President Trump, taking special satisfaction in offending Biden supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Where Does Joe Biden Stand on Major Policies?
description: Here’s an overview on President-elect Biden’s positions on coronavirus, health care, the economy, taxes and climate change.
content: Progressives think President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s policies do not go far enough. President Trump and his administration have called Mr. Biden a Trojan horse for the radical left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Here’s why the Georgia runoffs matter.
description: As the dust settles from the presidential race, the eyes of the political world have already shifted to Georgia, where two runoff elections set for early January will almost certainly determine which party has control of the Senate.
content: As the dust settles from the presidential race, the eyes of the political world have already shifted to Georgia, where two runoff elections set for early January will almost certainly determine which party has control of the Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Chinese State Media Reacts to Biden Victory With Cautious Optimism
description: Propaganda outlets said a Biden presidency would most likely restore stability to frayed U.S.-China relations, but warned that tensions would continue.
content: HONG KONG — The Chinese state news media reacted with cautious optimism to former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the United States presidential election, expressing hope that he would stabilize the fast-deteriorating relations between the two countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Trump supporters in Pennsylvania are furious, and they’re not going away.
description: PITTSBURGH — Like many Trump supporters, Dennis Tippie watched the steady tallying of votes that wiped away the president’s early lead in Pennsylvania, not with a faith that democracy was playing out but with dark and rising anger.
content: PITTSBURGH — Like many Trump supporters, Dennis Tippie watched the steady tallying of votes that wiped away the president’s early lead in Pennsylvania, not with a faith that democracy was playing out but with dark and rising anger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Can Joe and Mitch Get It Done?
description: The incoming Democratic president and top Senate Republican have personal ties and a history of deal-making that could shape the future of a Biden administration.
content: WASHINGTON — In late July 2011, with an economy-shaking Treasury default only a few days away and Congress flailing, Senator Mitch McConnell received a Saturday phone call from Joseph R. Biden Jr., then the vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: An Explanation for Some Covid-19 Deaths May Not Be Holding Up
description: Recent studies have created doubts about an agent in cytokine storms, and suggest that treatments for it may not help.
content: Medical researchers are raising significant doubts about whether an agent of the human immune system causes some coronavirus patients to end up in the hospital with injured lungs and other organs, struggling to breathe. What remains is a continuing mystery about what causes certain people to die from Covid-19, and how best to prevent that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Judith Levitt
title: Joe Biden, Coronavirus Surge, Thanksgiving: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was Biking Along Fifth Avenue in Brooklyn After Having a Burrito’
description: Running into a former colleague, making a delicious discovery and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak and Abby Goodnough
title: The Affordable Care Act Faces Another Supreme Court Test
description: Though the court’s conservative majority has been bolstered by three Trump appointees, the law’s challengers will face headwinds.
content: WASHINGTON — Eight years ago, the Affordable Care Act barely survived its first encounter with the Supreme Court. On Tuesday, a significantly more conservative court will hear arguments in a case brought by Republican state officials, backed by the Trump administration, seeking to destroy it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Nick Corasaniti
title: Which Four Seasons? Oh, not that one.
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the president’s personal lawyer, was standing in the parking lot of Four Seasons Total Landscaping in far northeast Philadelphia, as close to a Trump enclave as a decidedly Democratic city gets, highlighting alleged examples of voter fraud when the networks called the presidential race for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
content: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the president’s personal lawyer, was standing in the parking lot of Four Seasons Total Landscaping in far northeast Philadelphia, as close to a Trump enclave as a decidedly Democratic city gets, highlighting alleged examples of voter fraud when the networks called the presidential race for Joseph R. Biden Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Republican congressional leaders remain silent on Biden victory as Trump refuses to concede.
description: As President Trump refused to concede defeat on Saturday, top Republican congressional leaders followed suit, refraining from releasing the customary statements congratulating the victor that have been standard among senior lawmakers in both parties when a presidential election has been declared.
content: As President Trump refused to concede defeat on Saturday, top Republican congressional leaders followed suit, refraining from releasing the customary statements congratulating the victor that have been standard among senior lawmakers in both parties when a presidential election has been declared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg
title: There’s no evidence to support claims that election observers were blocked from counting rooms.
description: On Twitter and in interviews, President Trump and his supporters have alleged that his campaign observers were blocked from ballot-counting rooms, hindering their ability to witness and report several instances of what the Trump campaign has baselessly claimed was widespread election fraud that has marred the results.
content: On Twitter and in interviews, President Trump and his supporters have alleged that his campaign observers were blocked from ballot-counting rooms, hindering their ability to witness and report several instances of what the Trump campaign has baselessly claimed was widespread election fraud that has marred the results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Nick Corasaniti and Trip Gabriel
title: ‘It’s Such a Relief’: Biden Voters Rebuild a Wall That Trump Smashed
description: Joe Biden’s victory was particularly sweet for supporters in three states he had to win: Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Michigan.
content: AMBLER, Pa. — Kristyn LaBarge was on a walk when she found out, not from a smartphone alert or a call from a friend but from the loud banging of pots that something significant had happened — that Joseph R. Biden Jr. had made Donald J. Trump a one-term president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kerr and Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Biden Wins, and the Nation Reacts
description: A victory in Pennsylvania secured the electoral college vote for the Democratic nominee, Joseph R. Biden Jr. Across the nation, Biden supporters celebrated as Trump supporters gathered in protest. President Trump has vowed to continue to challenge the results in key states.
content: A victory in Pennsylvania secured the electoral college vote for the Democratic nominee, Joseph R. Biden Jr. Across the nation, Biden supporters celebrated as Trump supporters gathered in protest. President Trump has vowed to continue to challenge the results in key states.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: ‘The People of This Nation Have Spoken,’ Biden Says
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. celebrated his “convincing victory” and promised to seek to unify the country.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. celebrated his “convincing victory” and promised to seek to unify the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch: Biden Addressed Supporters, and the Nation
description: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris addressed the nation from Wilmington, Del.
content: President-elect Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Vice President-elect Kamala Harris addressed the nation from Wilmington, Del.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Harris Pays Tribute to Women Who Came Before Her
description: “I stand on their shoulders,” Vice President-elect Kamala Harris said in her victory speech on Saturday night.
content: “I stand on their shoulders,” Vice President-elect Kamala Harris said in her victory speech on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo and Katherine Cusumano
title: Nurture Your Plants and Your Kid’s Curiosity
description: This week, pick the best indoor plants, jam with the ‘queen of Kindie rock,’ dive deeper into the power of the X-ray and be swept away by the San Francisco Symphony.
content: Here is a sampling of the week’s events and how to tune in (all times are Eastern). Note that events are subject to change after publication.
